DOC.HEAD: Fire Burns Former Mill Complex
DOC.TEXT: A spectacular fire fed by oil-soaked wood floors burned a converted 126-year-old mill complex today in the biggest blaze in Providence history, officials said. Three firefighters suffered minor injuries. Up to 150 firefighters _ every one in the city and some from Rhode Island and Massachusetts _ battled the blaze in 17-degree weather. The fire gutted six of nine buildings in the complex, which had been converted to shops and other businesses. Fire Chief Michael F. Moise said it was ``the most extensive area of fire that we've ever seen in the city of Providence.'' The fire was declared under control about 1:30 a.m., eight hours after it began, but Moise said it could take three days to douse the hot spots at the complex of two- and four-story brick buildings spread over a quarter-mile. The cause of the fire was not immediately known. ``The floors were pretty well-oiled,'' said Fire Department spokesman Larry Donahue. ``They had machines that sat on those floors for years, and they were oiled every day over a period of 100 years or so. That makes them more flammable.''
